What is it? We'
column2: ve identified an issue where certain requests that should result in an error response are incorrectly returning responses with HTTP 200 status codes and an empty response body.

column1: Why it matters: These requests are in fact failing but are returning a successful response, when they should be returning an error. This incorrect response code occurs when the error response body is empty. This issue could affect any of our APIs, but there are two main instances where we'
column2:
ve seen this behavior:

  • `404 Not Found` errors, primarily when making a GET request for a specific record

column1: • `415 Unsupported Media Type` errors, primarily when making POST or PUT requests to create or update records when the request is missing the appropriate `content-type` request header.

Beginning on November 13th, these requests will begin returning the correct 4xx error codes. This may mean that you see an increase in 404 or other 4xx errors where HTTP 200 were previously being returned, and your integration may see these HTTP requests as failures where they previously looked like they were succeeding (again, these requests were not actually succeeding). No actual functionality will be changing, outside of the correct HTTP responses being returned.

If integrators or developers have questions:

They can ask questions and get answers in the HubSpot developers forum on this post. 

These changes should impact a relatively small number of live integrations and we'

",,,4,Integrating Hubspot using AWS API Gateways,,,,,"

Ignore the fancy terminology here: the AWS API Gateway is just a way to host an API for your app, which is on AWS infrastructure. And a Lambda function is just a fancy inline (sort-of) function that does some logic.

In short: we don't really care what the other side's infrastructure, language or method of doing logic is, as long is it can play ball with our authentication methods & REST API. Because our API is REST, it doesn't care what the other end is doing as long as the data being pushed or gotten (get'd?) is in the correct format.

Clarify the scenario with the prospect because someone who's a developer working with AWS Gateways & who works in Lambda functions (which are basically unreadable to anyone who doesn't write them in the first place) should know the answer from looking at our developer docs immediately.

Transactional email is the best way to send, and deliver, relationship-driven emails. But most transactional email is hard. For a marketer that wants to customize individual emails, it involves a significant amount of engineering time, and the marketer ends up losing control over the email. Welcome to the HubSpot Transactional Email Single-Send API. Marketers can create and send relationship-driven email from the same email interface within HubSpot, and use custom tokens that connect to customers APIs to insert information directly from their systems.
The single-send API combines the power integrating information from your own databases and utilizing the same interface and infrastructure with HubSpot.

We're excited to introduce CRM Extensions, a new public API specific to our CRM. This API allows developers to build integrations that bring their data and functionality inside the HubSpot CRM. The API goes public tomorrow, but two HubSpot Connect integration partners, PandaDoc and SeventhSense, have already built CRM integrations on the new API and more are on the way.
View the API Docs here. - (Not live yet)

Integrations using CRM Extensions can surface their own data in a card in the CRM sidebar for contacts, companies, or deals. When a contact, company, or deal record is loaded, HubSpot makes a request to the integrator, retrieves information for that record, and then display it on a card in the sidebar.

SOAP and REST
column2: are both ways to access Web services such as HubSpot or Salesforce.&nbsp
column3: SOAP is an older protocol typically scene in legacy Web Applications such as Sales Force.&nbsp

column1: REST is a newer protocol with a simpler method for accessing Web services. REST is the predominate protocol
column2: new Web applications such as HubSpot are adopting. In addition, many&nbsp
column3: legacy Web apps such as SalesForce&nbsp
column4: offer both a REST and SOAP&nbsp

column1: SOAP is a more rigid set of messaging patterns that relies on XML messaging. The XML can be complex, especially if you ware not using a wrapper for a particular SOAP service. In certain languages, such as .NET and Python, this issue is mitigated as popular SOAP services have wrappers that make interacting with the Web app simpler.
REST relies on standard HTTP verbs (GET, POST, PUT, and DELETE) to perform task. This eliminates the need for complex XML or developing a wrapper for the service. HubSpots API is RESTful so

The HubSpot - Eventbrite integration brings the power and scale of HubSpot contacts and marketing automation to offline events. Helping you better nurture leads generated from events and track which events best turn leads into customers.

How PandaDoc Speeds up the Sales Process with CRM Extensions

PandaDoc is sales enablement software that automates contracts, proposals, and quotes. PandaDoc helps CRM users close deals, completing the final step in an inbound customer journey. They’ve rebuilt their integration as a CRM Extension - here’s how it works.

1.) Connecting the integration

Inside of PandaDoc, in the settings users can find all integrations. Click on HubSpot and then follow the steps to authorise PandaDoc to access your instance of HubSpot CRM.

2.) Once installed users see a new card on the left hand side of contacts, companies, or deals for PandaDoc. If there is an existing document for that record, it will automatically be loaded. If there isn’t and you want to create a new one, to say send your prospect an NDA, simply launch PandaDoc from inside the CRM via a pop up modal window.

3.) Opening the modal window gives you full access to PandaDoc from within the CRM. So you can create new documents customize them for your prospect and quickly send them over.

4.) Because PandaDoc also integrates with the Timeline API, any activity taken by a contact with your sales documents will be reflected on the contact timeline.

How it works:

Technical Documentation

Why it matters:

This API enables an entirely new category of integrations. Any third party software whose customers use the HubSpot CRM should consider building on the integration. Why? HubSpot sales users live in the HubSpot CRM and they'

integrations/native",1,A Refreshed Install Experience for the Salesforce Integration,,,,,"

What is it?

A completely redesigned install wizard and setup flow for the Salesforce integration that’s cleaner, clearer, and more prescriptive.

Why is it important?

For HubSpot customers that use Salesforce as a CRM, setting up the integration correctly is critical to getting started on the right foot with HubSpot.

With today’s change, we’ve improved the setup experience in two ways:

  1. We’ve refreshed it with the Canvas style guide. It looks sleeker and more modern, and matches the rest of the HubSpot tools.

  2. We’ve made it more prescriptive. Instead of showing every user going through the setup process every bell and whistle included in the integration, we now provide two options: an advanced setup, for those who want complete control over every switch, and a “recommended” setup, which is a simpler and more streamlined process based on commonly used practices.

How it works?

When new customers go to install the Salesforce integration with HubSpot, they’ll be able to choose between a recommended setup and an advanced setup:

Recommended setup enables all Salesforce object syncs by default: leads, contacts, accounts and opportunities. All field mappings for those objects will be set to “Prefer Salesforce value unless value is blank.” All contacts will sync from HubSpot to Salesforce (no inclusion list, by default) and all Salesforce users will be imported into HubSpot.

Advanced setup allows you to choose which objects to sync. It also lets you decide on sync behavior for standard field mappings.

You’ll also be given the option to create/choose an inclusion list, and decide which Salesforce users you’d like to create in HubSpot.

Who gets it?

The new setup flow is now live to all integrated portals.

What language is it in?

All languages supported by HubSpot.

Source: Product Notifications

integrations/native",2,[Now Live] Bi-directional Sync for Salesforce Accounts and HubSpot Companies,,,,,"

What is it?

A little over a year ago we released a beta of bi-directional account sync with HubSpot companies and Salesforce accounts. This week, this feature will now be released to all integrated portals. HubSpot will now create accounts in Salesforce and manage re-associations.

Why is it important?

Our integration with Salesforce lets you use both systems to meet the unique needs of your organization. Having information sync seamlessly between the two systems is integral to keeping your sales, marketing, and service teams on the same page when it comes to interactions with your customers.

This becomes difficult to manage when there are discrepancies between what you see in HubSpot, and what you see in Salesforce. In the past, you had to wait until an account was created and associated with a contact in Salesforce, then have it sync back to HubSpot to have a HubSpot company sync directly with a Salesforce account. With this update, you can now create company records in HubSpot that will automatically sync bi-directionally with their associated contact in HubSpot, just as you would expect them to.

How does it work?

Now, if your Salesforce settings are set to create new contacts in Salesforce when a new contact is created within HubSpot, and that contact is associated to a company in HubSpot, we will automatically create a new account record in Salesforce for the associated company. The new contact and account records will be associated in Salesforce just like they are in HubSpot.

Note: We will not create new account records in Salesforce if you have this setting set to create new lead records in Salesforce. Once the lead is converted to a Salesforce contact then the Salesforce account will sync with the HubSpot company.

There are a few other nuances to this update that are important to keep in mind…

  • If a newly created HubSpot contact syncs over to an existing contact record in Salesforce, and the Salesforce contact record is already associated to an account record, we will honor the Salesforce account ID on the contact record. Any associated company in HubSpot will be synced to the already associated account record in Salesforce.

  • If the association between a contact and a company is changed within either HubSpot or Salesforce, that update will sync to the other system automatically.

  • If you do not want HubSpot automatically creating accounts within Salesforce, we recommend turning off the setting within Contacts & Companies settings that automatically creates and associates companies with contacts based on their email address and company domain.

Sharing the news with customers

Feel free to share this product updated blog post with any interested customers.

Who gets it?

This is now live to all integrated portals.

What language is it in?

All languages supported by HubSpot.

Source: Product Notifications

115,Survey Monkey,,,integrations/native,1,Sync Speed Improvements,,,,,"

What is it?

HubSpot has increased the speed it takes to sync SurveyMonkey data to HubSpot from hours to minutes.

 

Why does it matter?

In the past, HubSpot would check for new SurveyMonkey responses every 7-10 hours. This made real-time automation hard if you wanted to use this data for your HubSpot Workflows. It also kept relevant context away from your sales team, preventing them from having the full context when entering into a conversation with a prospect. This delay caused a considerable amount of pain and confusion for users who integrated with SurveyMonkey.

 

With today’s update, the native SurveyMonkey integration has increased its sync speed from 7-10 hours to a matter of minutes. This means that as soon as you receive a response to one of your surveys, you can expect that data to sync to HubSpot, so your team can take action on these contacts.

 

How does it work?

Instead of a scheduled “pull” of data between HubSpot and SurveyMonkey, the integration now uses webhooks to listen for new responses as they come in to SurveyMonkey. No action is required on your part for this increased speed in syncing to take effect.

 

For more information on our integration with SurveyMonkey, feel free to refer to this updated knowledge doc.

 

Who gets it?

We are in the process of rolling this speed improvement out to all integrated portals. These speed improvements will be ready for all integrated portals to take advantage of within the next 24 hours.

 

Sharing the news with customersFeel free to share this product update blog post with any interested customers.

 

What language is it in?

All languages supported by HubSpot.

132,Wordpress,,,,3,Why are contacts being created in WordPress that haven't converted on my website?,,,,,"

When customers install the HubSpot tracking code on their site using the HubSpot < -> Wordpress plugin, there are instances where the plugin will create contacts based on who is in the users table within WordPress. WordPress, unlike HubSpot, does not differentiate between users (i.e. administrators of Wordpress) and visitors who have subscribed to your blog.

For example, I am Ashley and I am an administrator of WordPress. I write blog posts and build pages on the site. Bob is an anonymous visitor on my site who decides he wants to subscribe to my Wordpress blog. Both myself and Bob would be added to the users table within WordPress, even though we are different kinds of users (Admin vs Subscriber). In HubSpot, we both get created as contacts because we've been active on the site, logging in, etc.
There is no exact rhyme or reason why this happens for some customers and not for others.
column2: The solution is to make sure the most recent version of the plugin is used OR&nbsp
column3: remove the HubSpot < -> WordPress plugin from WordPress and manually install the HubSpot tracking code into the head tag on the WordPress site.

What is it?

Zoom is video communication software that powers video meetings, webinars, and more. This new, native (HubSpot built), integration brings Zoom video meetings to the HubSpot CRM and meetings tool as well as adds a new Zoom webinar action to workflows.

Fill out this form to request access for your personal or customer portals. (We’ll ungate weekly)

Why it matters:

Physical distance isn’t an obstacle for growth like it used to be. With tools like G-Suite, Slack, and HubSpot, it’s easy to work with clients, customers, and prospects from all over the world.

These tools may connect us like never before but we often miss nonverbal cues we’d notice in person: the shrug of disappointment a customer shares in a strategy meeting
column2:
the tears of joy shed by a prospect after an expertly timed joke. These are the little things that remind us we’re all people and help us grow better.

Video is as close as we can get to an in-person meeting. And having more video meetings as opposed to long emails and phone calls helps you grow better. Better relationships with new clients, better conversations with struggling customers, and better connections with your marketing audiences. Zoom is a world class video meetings and webinar provider and now it integrates seamlessly with HubSpot.

How it works:

  1. Navigate to all integrations in-app, and search for Zoom.

2. Once connected it’s easier to create and track Zoom meetings from the CRM and meetings.

  • Salespeople can insert a Zoom meeting link in one click when scheduling a meeting directly from the CRM.

  • Meetings users will see a new Location option under the Configuration setting. When you select Zoom for the location an automatic Zoom meeting link is added to individual meetings, group meetings, or round robin.

3. The Zoom integration also makes it easy to use HubSpot to deliver your Zoom webinars.

  • Once connected you will see a new Zoom webinar action in workflows.

  • You can then use workflows to add a contact to Zoom Webinar list as a registered participant.

  • Registering a contact in Zoom automatically sets a Webinar ID property which can be used in emails to provide dial-in information.

Who gets it:

The integration is free for any users with HubSpot and Zoom. The meetings/CRM integration is available for free users, but to use the webinar integration customers will need workflows and thus Marketing Pro or higher.

141,Zendesk,,,integrations/hubspot-connect,4,What is the difference between a Zendesk Automation and a Zendesk Trigger,,,,,"

The differences between automations and triggers highlight two different aspects of your support workflow: time and action. You want to have a clear understanding of when you should use an automation and when you should use a trigger.

Automations within Zendesk Support are specifically time-based. You use them when you want an action to automatically happen according to a timeframe you've set up in your workflow. Automations run every hour on all your tickets that are not closed.
As the example shows, your support workflow should have some time requirements -- whether they are specific goals of when you'll respond to a request
column2: or more general expectations about the time a ticket needs to remain solved before you can officially close it.

column1: One way to think about when and how to set up an automation is to write out your support workflow and indicate if you have any time requirements associated with any of the steps. Say you want to send out a reminder email to your customer if you've been waiting for information from them for over three days. Perfect time for an automation. Rather than having to remember to send that reminder out
column2: or manually go through your tickets, the automation can automatically keep you on schedule.

column1: Zendesk Support comes with some default automations -- click the Admin icon in the sidebar, then select Business rules > Automations to see them -- but we encourage you to think through your support workflow as a time-based sequence and add more as needed.

column3: <a href=""https://support.zendesk.com/entries/20012032-Streamlining-workflow-with-time-based-events-and-automations"">Streamlining workflow with time-based events and automations&nbsp

column1: Triggers within Zendesk Support fire when other specific actions have taken place. Triggers are run through every time a ticket state is changed, and literally triggered if the changes match the conditions defined in the trigger.

You use triggers when you want certain actions to take place only when some other actions have taken place. For example, you want to send out a particular answer to a question when that question comes in. If another type of question comes in, you want another set of actions to take place. So every time a ticket is touched, changes attributes, or has a comment added, the system checks if any of the trigger conditions match the change and fires them off.

To set up your triggers, take that same support workflow that you created for automations and map out how those steps connect. At all those connection points think about whether you can automate the process.

You might not be able to automate the research it takes to troubleshoot a ticket for instance, but you can automate the ticket's escalation. When the agent assigns the ticket to another group, for instance, you can create a trigger that fires off an email to the members of that group.
Zendesk Support comes with some default few triggers -- click the Admin icon in the sidebar, then select Business rules > Triggers to see them
column3: -- but, again, we encourage you to customize them and add more to fit your workflow.
